Education the sum of $250,000, for

$75o,oco be contributed by the University in cash or pledged to the

HOMEWOOD
•
The objects for which this fund
is to be used in part and for which
it is hoped that additional amounts,
reaching a total of at least $2,000,coo,
may be raised in the future were
stated by the President of the University on February 22 last, and were
printed in the last Alumni number of
the News-Letter. Of these needs the
most imperative relate to the removal of the University to Homewood
and the erection there of such buildings as will provide accommodations
for both graduate and undergradHomewood is
uate departments.
a tract of 120 acres, admirably located, in a portion of the city which is
rapidly becoming one of the delightful residential sections of Baltimore.
Extensive improvements in the way
of parks and boulevards have already
been made by the city authorities and
during the last three years noteworthy changes have been made in
the appearance of what was a decade
ago an open area of largely unoccupied country. The extension of the
trolley system has brought this section of Baltimore into close connection with the centre of the city and
the time is ripe for a movement
which will transfer by slow stages
the University from its present unattractive surroundings to a site
which will offer every advantage
from the standpoint of health and
beauty.
The perspective view of the proposed buildings at Homewood present
a picture of remarkable architectural
and physical charm. Massed in two
groups of structures surrounding
each a court oblong in shape and capable of rich adornment from the
standpoint of the landscape gardener,
the new university and college buildings will, when completed, form a

Price, 5 cents per copy.
centre of academic work and life unsurpassed in this country. Symmetrical in plan and harmonious in style
they find their only parallel among
structures similarly designed beforehand, as in the case of those of the
University of California to which
they bear a certain resemblance, as
far as the ground plan is concerned.
The main group occupying the centre of the Homewood tract is arranged somewhat after the lines of
a great cathedral. The library occupies the place of the chancel and
Lady Chapel, the chapel and museums that of the left transept, and
the administration and
academic
buildings with the gateway that of
the right transept.
Along the
aisles, corresponding in position to
the lesser chapels of a cathedral are
the six laboratories, three on each
side, while at the end where would
stand the great front of the cathedral
is the chief museum, itself built
about two inner courts. The entire
inner portion, the nave and the choir,
forms the oblong court, divided into
two quadrangles. At a short distance to the north, running along the
edge of Charles Street, and former
Merriman's Lane, now the University Parkway, lie the buildings of the
college dormitories and gymnasium—
t.early a dozen in number, terminating in the present athletic field, upon
the southeastern side of which the
gymnasium will stand. The architectural style of the buildings, the
keynote of which is found in the
cld Carroll Mansion, one of the finest structures of colonial design in
the South, is admirable for its simBuilt of red
plicity and dignity.
brick with white trimmings and reproducing whenever possible the impressive columnal scheme of the
portico of the old house, these buildings will represent in their external
appearance an architectural design
that is not only exceedingly beautiful in itself and well adapted to the
purpose for which they are intended
but is also in harmony with the characteristic colonial architecture of the
old South. Thus the present Carroll mansion, which will remain to
flank the entrance driveway on the
north as the future president's house
of similar design will flank it on the
south, will strike no discordant note
in the general scheme. The fine entrance gateway, connecting the administration and academic buildings
and with them forming a very effective front to the observer approaching
from Charles Street, is also colonial
in design, reminding one on a larg-

In looking toward Homewood as
its future home the Johns Hopkins
University is but aiming to do
what a score of other institutions
have been compelled to do in the
last quarter of a century—to move
"up town" or into the suburbs. The
growth of suburban life, the encroachment of business interests upoa
the old residential districts, the increasing undesirableness, from the
standpoint of health and physical
needs, of a location in the heart of a
city are all forcing the University to
change its situation. The present position offers little opportunity for
expansion. Cramped and crowded,
exposed to the dust and dirt of the
city, and in certain of its quarters
hampered by inadequate light and
disturbed by persistent noise the
University needs the openness, cleanliness, and quiet of the larger area.
ADDITIONAL OBJECTS
Among the important objects for
which the new fund is to be used are
a school of engineering, a law school,
a school for teachers, a department
of preventive medicine, and a pathological institute.
School of Higher Engineering. —
There is a great demand at the present time for such an institution of
applied science to which the graduates of technical schools and also
practicing engineers may come and
conduct research work in the most
proficient manner. Such a school
would bear the same relation to the
technical schools as a university does
to a college. The development of
technical instruction, it seems, has
not kept pace with the marvelous industrial growth of the country and
there is probably no university in the
country which is better able to undertake such an important work as is

a tract of 120 acres, admirably located, in a portion of the city which is
rapidly becoming one of the delightful residential sections of Baltimore.
Extensive improvements in the way
of parks and boulevards have already
been made by the city authorities and
during the last three years noteworthy changes have been made in
the appearance of what was a decade
ago an open area of largely unoccupied country. The extension of the
trolley system has brought this section of Baltimore into close connection with the centre of the city and
the time is ripe for a movement
which will transfer by slow stages
the University from its present unattractive surroundings to a site
which will offer every advantage
from the standpoint of health and
beauty.
The perspective view of the proposed buildings at Homewood present
a picture of remarkable architectural
and physical charm. Massed in two
groups of structures surrounding
each a court oblong in shape and capable of rich adornment from the
standpoint of the landscape gardener,
the new university and college buildings will, when completed, form a

Price, 5 cents per copy.
centre of academic work and life unsurpassed in this country. Symmetrical in plan and harmonious in style
they find their only parallel among
structures similarly designed beforehand, as in the case of those of the
University of California to which
they bear a certain resemblance, as
far as the ground plan is concerned.
The main group occupying the centre of the Homewood tract is arranged somewhat after the lines of
a great cathedral. The library occupies the place of the chancel and
Lady Chapel, the chapel and museums that of the left transept, and
the administration and
academic
buildings with the gateway that of
the right transept.
Along the
aisles, corresponding in position to
the lesser chapels of a cathedral are
the six laboratories, three on each
side, while at the end where would
stand the great front of the cathedral
is the chief museum, itself built
about two inner courts. The entire
inner portion, the nave and the choir,
forms the oblong court, divided into
two quadrangles. At a short distance to the north, running along the
edge of Charles Street, and former
Merriman's Lane, now the University Parkway, lie the buildings of the
college dormitories and gymnasium—
t.early a dozen in number, terminating in the present athletic field, upon
the southeastern side of which the
gymnasium will stand. The architectural style of the buildings, the
keynote of which is found in the
cld Carroll Mansion, one of the finest structures of colonial design in
the South, is admirable for its simBuilt of red
plicity and dignity.
brick with white trimmings and reproducing whenever possible the impressive columnal scheme of the
portico of the old house, these buildings will represent in their external
appearance an architectural design
that is not only exceedingly beautiful in itself and well adapted to the
purpose for which they are intended
but is also in harmony with the characteristic colonial architecture of the
old South. Thus the present Carroll mansion, which will remain to
flank the entrance driveway on the
north as the future president's house
of similar design will flank it on the
south, will strike no discordant note
in the general scheme. The fine entrance gateway, connecting the administration and academic buildings
and with them forming a very effective front to the observer approaching
from Charles Street, is also colonial
in design, reminding one on a larg-

In looking toward Homewood as
its future home the Johns Hopkins
University is but aiming to do
what a score of other institutions
have been compelled to do in the
last quarter of a century—to move
"up town" or into the suburbs. The
growth of suburban life, the encroachment of business interests upoa
the old residential districts, the increasing undesirableness, from the
standpoint of health and physical
needs, of a location in the heart of a
city are all forcing the University to
change its situation. The present position offers little opportunity for
expansion. Cramped and crowded,
exposed to the dust and dirt of the
city, and in certain of its quarters
hampered by inadequate light and
disturbed by persistent noise the
University needs the openness, cleanliness, and quiet of the larger area.
ADDITIONAL OBJECTS
Among the important objects for
which the new fund is to be used are
a school of engineering, a law school,
a school for teachers, a department
of preventive medicine, and a pathological institute.
School of Higher Engineering. —
There is a great demand at the present time for such an institution of
applied science to which the graduates of technical schools and also
practicing engineers may come and
conduct research work in the most
proficient manner. Such a school
would bear the same relation to the
technical schools as a university does
to a college. The development of
technical instruction, it seems, has
not kept pace with the marvelous industrial growth of the country and
there is probably no university in the
country which is better able to undertake such an important work as is
